lam155_v15_tawgih1.body:
Tawǧīh: the words ẓāhirī and muʿtazilī (in rhyme position for muʿtazil), which denote a person adhering to the theological schools Ẓāhiriyyah and Muʿtazilah respectively, have here their common lexical meaning.
Cf. art. Tawgih in Figurenlexikon.

lam155_v34_tawgih1.body:
Tawǧīh: the words munsariḥ and ramal, the names of two poetic metres, have here their common meaning.
Cf. art. Tawgih in Figurenlexikon.

lam155_v10_tawriyah1.body:
All manuscripts have ǧadal, “argument, debate, dispute”. Given the juridical context, this seems to be the correct reading, but Ibn Nubātah apparently puns on the vernacular pronunciation of the word ǧaḏal, “joy”.
Cf. art. Tawriyah in Figurenlexikon.
